comments.commentBody: AND how absurd is that - in another opinion two dudes, who warn on the opinion pages of the NYT about 'backfire' to warning about climate change - prove all of dear Prof. points about 'Asymetric stupidity'...
oh Vladimir; was it old ladies who seized the security services buildings, mined them and seized weapons? Really?

Just a few words. It was not me, it is a man who left the Soviet Union and settled in Brooklyn in late 1980's - who said it is the two words which  show the Western attitude towards Russia - Arrogance and Ignorance. How would you enjoy the words "Russia warn US and NATO over something"? In the Soviet Union it was spelled the "cold war", always in the quotation marks, in the West it is the Cold War.

According to solidarity principles crimea is important to both ukraine and the russian federation because without this 'peninsula' there would not be free trade in the region as a  conduit to trade routes that are in existence over the world. Annexation has disrupted the stability in this region and opened old wounds that exist throughout the last century.. we are a social species and also an aggressive one. It is important that we deescalate the moves toward war. A land route to crimea may fit in with russian federation's plans for the region but a war must be taken off the table. It would spiral into the conflagration that everyone fears. We have been living with the nuclear threat for a long while now. In the early days  of crimea's annexation there was an increased danger that we would go against this by declarations of war. Ukraine is a breakaway state. It is only natural that there be recriminations within ukraine  about this choice made in the '90s. We should be careful about words that are mistaken as violence. This social question drives each and every one of us, not only the peoples in ukraine. It is a question of identity and how people are treated and also dependent on the memories of the living and what they are used to. I don't choose to be placed in the middle of this argument although it is part to my upbringing that I be interested.
Annexing eastern Ukraine would benefit Russia about as much as annexing southern Ontario would benefit the U.S.  They're already pretty much on our side.  Why would we want to own them?

Mr. Thomason: The point of most observers on the ground, including OSCE observers, is that the separatist protest movement is not one that has attracted the vast majority of the population of these regions. I'm glad to read you know accord Ukrainians the rights to determine their own fates as a democracy, as you yesterday dismissed them as an "artificial country" in frankly contemptuous tones; a country which Russia has veto rights over, as if the US has the right to intervene in Canada and Mexico given proximity.

I'd like to know if you have ever been to Ukraine, any part will do. Know any Ukrainians, or have studied their history, particularly under Stalin and the artificial famine, to see why independence from Russia is so prized. Despite the Ukrainian Jewish communities tragic history in that country, even they oppose Putin's threatened invasion and fear Russian autocracy (as another NYT article here makes clear). My family background, in part, is rooted in that history and I find your dismissal of Ukrainians aspirations for freedom and democracy, frankly problematic if not offensive.

The plane is probably lost, too much time wasted early on.

Hopefully, changes will be implemented such that all passenger planes will continuously be tracked from departure to safe arrival.

Flight 370 left at 12:41 AM, at 7:24 AM it was announced contact had been lost.

That is most unacceptable.

Oh dear, what a detractor once called my "fabulous kumbaya" approach (I wish I was that nice) may distract from the point I was trying to make. I'm asking for a different kind and quality of mutual caring for each other and the environment. We are a very large family of humankind, and instead of fighting about this and that, I believe our best last hope is to start pulling together and pay attention to the accumulated wisdom available to us all.

As to spectacle, I just saw Noah. I don't see how the appetite we seem to have for extravagant horrors in fictional work has made us too delicate to face a few hard facts. We need some backbone, not false comfort.
Before submitting snarky blather consider how and where the transducers are towed and deployed.
You'll find from the full sequence of images the diver was retrieving debris from the surface for testing. Wasn't part of the black box detection operation.

I'd wager that the plane landed somewhere considering the expertise that went into rerouting it.
This plane is not in the water. Thats what they want you to think. Consider the carefully orchestrated false leads...and now talks about giving up. They are looking in this part of a vast ocean based on nothing but assumptions of critical parameters like speed and direction. This is all theater to convince us that the plane is in the water which means that it is somewhere else.

Yes, the Money should be invested in Electronics, in general safety and quality Culture.
Sorry to say, but it looks like "modern medicine". It is active in emergency but lazy in prevention, and the third party is paying but not for quality.

Yes, password thieves have stolen data.

If they intercept messages between you and a site, and they steal the key from that site, then they can read all of those messages. If the messages contain things like your password, credit card, etc, then they can read them.

A site can fix the flaw to prevent the key from being stolen. Then, they can change keys to prevent future messages from being read, too. But there's nothing they or you can do about old messages and a stolen key. Further, there's no way to tell when a key is stolen -- the thief leaves no traces -- so you should assume that all keys have been stolen, unless a site guarantees otherwise (for example, affirms that they were not using an affected version of OpenSSL).

I think you're being too generous with Bush II and his 'winsome' paintings, Maureen. His portrait of his former friend, Putin, is a grotesque, likely to evoke nightmares in small children, and his own self portrait is oddly revealing, a kind of cynical, smarmy snake oil guy.

In the context of what he, Cheney, Wolfowitz, et al did to this country, and brother Jeb's ushering his brother into the White House, I agree whole heartedly with Jeb's mother Barbara, not another Bush ... please.

That's a lot of native-born Americans who are presumably competing with undocumented migrant workers for field-hand jobs (or as gardners for the Romneys).  It's all good, though: Republicans will continue to garner the votes of virtually no Latinos outside of south Florida's Cuban-American community and will continue to lose national elections as a consequence.

There are a couple of things you can do short of that. Some people keep a separate small bank account for online transactions. Another strategy is to keep a bootable Linux CD in your computer. Boot into that to do online banking. Another of course is to use a separate, dedicated computer. And always use strong passwords, of course.

That doesn't protect you against everything -- a server could always be hacked, as it was here -- but nothing is foolproof -- even if you don't use a computer at all, there are various ways your money can be stolen. I had someone behind me in line make a withdrawal from my account once, even though his attempt to copy my signature was nominal at best (the teller, a trainee, was fired for accepting it).

After having one bank account and a credit card hacked a few years ago, I do all my banking in person. Paypal payments are drawn from an account that I keep less than $300 in at any time unless I plan for a larger purchase. The credit card I use has a $1,000 limit. It's a pain but I use the internet to take advantage of lower cost and more product choices than I can get locally. I also use my equity/stock account as a bank account, storing some cash there (Rightly or wrongly, I feel like the security is good there). What else can you do? If I'm phished, I begin to change my passwords. I have five different email accounts and I will not bank from my phone.

The problem allows all messages sent to/from a site to be stolen and read, and this remains true of all messages until that site is fixed. So, there's no point in changing anything until a site is fixed.
Who's worried about the NSA now?

If this were not open source, it probably would not have been found till after a huge heist and then it would be covered up and the researchers threatened with jail time if they exposed the bug or even talked about its existence. At least this is what happens in the proprietary code world at this time.

So, in answer to your question regarding open source standards and practices (of which there are many, many variations,) rather than calling open source into question, it shows the power of open source to detect, publicize, and fix its own faults.

@RichWa: It seems to me your argument hinges on the notion that, whether proprietary or open source, the likelihood is more or less the same that this vulnerability would first be discovered by malicious persons.

But how did attackers find this bug if not by combing through the publicly available source code? Sure, we can make the case that "whitehats" also have the same ability to try and identify vulnerabilities in the code, but who has the greater incentive to succeed? Clearly the "bad guys" do. For them, finding this sort of vulnerability means pay day, whereas for everyone else every minute and dollar invested in finding and fixing these problems is one not spent elsewhere. Where one side finds nothing but opportunity the other side experiences nothing by opportunity cost.

So one way of looking at it is to say that open source places "blackhats" and "whitehats" on an even playing field, except that blackhats have everything to gain while the rest of us can only ever try and manage the extent to which we lose. In the proprietary world, these incentives are unchanged, but the private organizations who own the code presumably maintain the upper hand of exclusive access to it, making the blackhat's job significantly more challenging.

Now, maybe all those extra eyes make open source code sufficiently more polished that the extra vulnerability is mitigated. But this disaster still happened, and attempting to spin it as a "win" for open source is kind of a joke.

I'm certainly not a fan of Open Source now that I've had to start using some Open Source development software.  The documentation is often woefully inadequate - though that's a trend that started with Microsoft "back in the day."  I long for the days when IBM dominated and everything that I needed to know was well-documented.

Okay folks, does this OpenSSL fiasco call into
question the Open Source movement?
No, not the Open Source movement per se,
but rather its standards and practices.
Was this "heartbeat" nuance so obscure
as not to be detectable by proper code reviews?
Interesting timing.  Just when April 15 th looms...
Hopefully, they're getting smart and weeding out the cheaters, passed-alongs and those with an 8th grade reading level who somehow made it into gifted classes.

OR please NYT - next time - could you warn your readers about such surprising satire in the opinion pages?

What's about putting a big fat WARNING sign in frot of it?
-(or you might get 'backfire' from readers who take such satire seriously?)

Simply not true.  They are crassly trawling for more applications.  You should see the mailings--weekly at some points--directed at upper middle class students here where I live. The sad thing is they work!

I am glad that the University of Chicago is making a massive effort to reach out to underprivileged neighborhoods where families would not have otherwise considered applying to Chicago.

It is not mass marketing just to get its acceptance rate down, as one reader complained: "We have a Harlem zip code. Now imagine all the poor kids near us getting similar fliers..."

Now imagine just one of those poor kids getting in Chicago. That poor kid could have been Michele Obama, who grew up near the University of Chicago, but has said in countless interviews that she never even considered applying there because she felt she just didn't belong there (and the irony is that she felt Princeton, where she went to, was more accepting than Chicago).

Chicago is trying to rectify that, whether it be a misperception of the school or historical legacy of the schol, so kudos to the University.

Indeed, I hope Chicago is bombarding the White House with marketing material to try to convince Malia and Sasha to apply!
Maybe they should also consider applying to Canadian Universities for good value education at much lower fees than charged by US Ivy colleges and universities.

I never thought I would be defending the jocks, but given that they are unpaid/illegal labor and huge profit centers for the university, the least the university can do in return is give them a passable education and a brand-name diploma.

Our college-sports (and professional sports) situation is beyond dysfunctional, but until America breaks up with ESPN (hahaha), but the fixing of that is not the purview of 18-22-year-old young adults.

The kids might as well get their payday in some form; kudos to young athlete for rightfully taking a free ride as their due value in the market. The pre-med kids and the pre-law kids only get their first checks years down the line, and *then they have to start paying off their school debts.

Note to self: Sign the children up for Little League.

Sheesh. Harvard can admit anyone it wants, it's endowment is bigger than some countries' GDP. It has intentionally chosen to include more and more students from other-than-rich backgrounds. Need-based financial aid is enormously generous so Harvard is simply NOT expensive -- the only students who have to pay much are those who really can afford it, while everyone else gets subsidized. Hardly anyone who gets admitted is unable to attend because the family can't afford it, and I do believe their statements that admission does not look at the family's financial means. It's true being a white, middle-class American with a stable home life provides advantages in life -- it certainly qualifies as "privileged" in the global sense. But this has nothing to do with the kind of elitist stereotype people are talking about here. You can get into an Ivy League school with intelligence, hard work, some personal accomplishment that you bring to the table and is perceived as contributing to the college community, and, sure, some luck. But it doesn't take an affluent family. And it doesn't take "tutors and consultants," just parents and maybe one or two teachers.

Parents: raise good kids, love them unconditionally, encourage them, be proud of them, let them know you really value their hard work, and work as hard as you can to connect them with opportunities to accomplish things -- and then see what kind of results you get. It won't matter where they end up going to college either.
